Award.AwardTitle: Intramyocellular Biotransport and Muscle Quality in Aging and Obesity

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1236451

PI: Georgiadis

Aging and obesity are associated with reductions in lean body mass and increases in fat mass, both leading to declines in strength and physical function. Elderly women are particularly prone to disability as they have more fat mass, less skeletal muscle mass and strength, and are less physically active compared to their male counterparts. Determining fitness for the elderly who are overweight or obese by using non-invasive means will facilitate intervention by diet and exercise. This project is motivated by the need to measure the relative benefits of these interventions to increase leg muscle quality, which is a measure of physical fitness. Recent research has demonstrated that Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) can measure the local properties of directional water diffusion and lipid concentration in the human muscle. A systematic study of the thigh muscles of 47 elderly women differing in weight and fitness level has just been completed, including a follow-up study after exercise training and weight loss of the obese subgroup. Strong correlations were found between overall fitness and MRI measures related to transport of water inside the muscle fibers. The overarching aim of this project is to interpret these results by simulating the way MRI encodes information and applying these simulations to understand the transport of metabolites within the muscle fiber. Human muscle is a complex hierarchical tissue, so the focus of this project is on a multiphase model that can accommodate the muscle structural changes relevant to aging and obesity. Starting from the MRI data acquired, the model will include an ordered or disordered array of myofibrils and lipid domains inside the muscle fiber, and multiphase transport of water, certain metabolites, and calcium ions will be simulated numerically. The model parameters will then be altered judiciously to study various scenarios of mass transport related to impaired metabolism inside the muscle fiber. The key objective of the proposed research is the combination of numerical modeling with data obtained from non-invasive imaging techniques, such as MRI, which will offer insights into muscle physiology and metabolism previously only available from invasive techniques requiring muscle biopsy. The connection between local directional diffusion and the distribution of the lipids inside the muscle has not been explored, because ostensibly such measurements have not been possible until now.

Among the 81 million baby boomers currently living in the US, 70% of women over 60 years of age are overweight or obese. The transformative part of this project is the use of MRI technology available in the local clinic to connect the physical fitness of the individual with the physics of mass transport inside the muscle. In addition to helping plan the clinical intervention in order to prevent the onset of disabilities, this project will improve scientific knowledge of how the aging muscle utilizes energy derived from lipids. Knowledge gained from this research effort can be incorporated into classical engineering courses, or new interdisciplinary courses. The future establishment of an NSF Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program focusing on Transport Phenomena in Muscle and Central Nervous System is also planned.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project relies on the fact that most water in live tissues obeys simple passive diffusion physics, and that there exist special Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) to quantify the diffusion parameters. Under a prior NIH study, we employed such techniques to measure the local properties of directional water diffusion and lipid concentration in the human muscle in vivo. As part of that study, nineteen obese, elderly women (mean BMI: 33, mean age: 65 years) were randomly separated into two groups, one of which (10 women) involved exercise-based intervention combining endurance and strength training. An MR imaging volume around the midpoint of the left thigh muscle of each subject (see Figure 1(a)) was scanned before and after the intervention using two special MRI techniques (Diffusion Tensor Imaging and Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy). Strong correlations were found between overall fitness outcomes and the MRI outcomes. The goal of this project was to interpret these results by simulating the way MRI encodes information and by applying these simulations to understand the transport of water within the muscle fiber. The import of this understanding is to tease out microstructural changes in the muscle without requiring invasive techniques like muscle biopsy. Human muscle is a complex hierarchical tissue, so the focus of this project is on a multiphase model that can accommodate the muscle structural changes relevant to aging and obesity. An efficient numerical method (Lattice Boltzmann scheme) was developed based on a multi-compartment tissue model consisting of an array of myofibers surrounded by a uniform domain representing the extracellular matrix (see Figure 1(b)), with both compartments consisting of dilute concentrations of lipid inclusions (representing myocellular lipids). The simulation predicts the MRI signal from Diffusion Tensor Imaging, while certain parameters for the simulation (such as local muscle lipid concentration) can be derived from the Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy measurements. By performing thousands of simulations, we then determined that the most important parameters are the diffusion properties of water inside and outside the myofibers, and we connected these to the myocellular lipid concentration. Finally we proved that the model predicts correctly the change in MRI outcomes with physical exercise.

 

The intellectual merit of this project is the development of an efficient computational model, which incorporates multiple physiological parameters that can measured with MRI, and simulates the way MRI encodes information. This can increase the specificity of in vivo human muscle MRI, as well as of imaging other tissues with fibrous microstructure. The most likely practical import of this project is the use of MRI technology available in the local clinic to connect the physical fitness of the individual with the physics of mass transport inside the muscle. This is particularly useful in the field of aging. Among the 81 million “baby boomers” currently living in the US, 70% of women over 60 years of age are overweight or obese. Elderly women are particularly prone to disability as they have more fat mass, less skeletal muscle mass and strength, and are less physically active compared to their male counterparts. Determining fitness for the elderly who are overweight or obese by using non-invasive means will facilitate intervention by diet and exercise. This project promises to increase the scientific knowledge of how the aging muscle of obese individuals redistributes lipids stored between the myofibers following exercise. This affects the transport of water and low molecular weight metabolites through the multiphase matrix of the myofiber bundles and ultimately impacts energy utilization. The combination of multiphase modeling with data obtained from non-invasive imaging techniques, such as MRI, will offer insights into muscle physiology and metabolism previously only available from invasive techniques requiring muscle biopsy.
